docs.snippet: “On May 24, 1951, a young center fielder who had dazzled crowds in the minor leagues left Sioux City, Iowa, traveling light.”...
docs.lead_paragraph: “On May 24, 1951, a young center fielder who had dazzled crowds in the minor leagues left Sioux City, Iowa, traveling light.”

docs.snippet: The long road "Crazy Heart" took from book to movie winded through Chuck Barris and the post-modernist writer Donald Barthelme....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the surprising list of people who benefit from Oscar nominations - stylists, make-up artists, awards consultants, bloggers - let's add Thomas Cobb, author. Mr. Cobb, 62, wrote the novel "Crazy Heart," which was the basis of the movie that's meant to give Jeff Bridges his long-overdue Academy Award. First published 23 years ago, the book was well received but sold only about 11,000 copies; re-released on Feb. 2 by HarperCollins - complete with photo of Mr. Bridges on the cover - it has already racked up five times that in sales and pre-orders. The film, too, has received more of an Oscar box office boost than its fellow nominees, according to The Los Angeles Times.
docs.abstract: The long road "Crazy Heart" took from book to movie winded through Chuck Barris and the post-modernist writer Donald Barthelme.

docs.snippet: Many of the big players will be spending much less than what they did a decade ago, on marketing their hopefuls....
docs.lead_paragraph: In addition to the new math of voting, this season Oscar campaigners have new math for budgeting and timing. To accommodate the Olympics, the telecast has been pushed back two weeks later than normal, to March 7th. Which gives studios and their acolytes extra days to spend and woo.
docs.abstract: Many of the big players will be spending much less than what they did a decade ago, on marketing their hopefuls.

headline.main: The New Math of Oscar Advertising

docs.snippet: The filmmakers may have moved one step closer to their goal of stopping the dolphin slaughter that the documentary depicts....
docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 10:07 a.m. The filmmakers behind "The Cove" have been open about their goal: not to win an Oscar - though they wouldn't mind - but to stop the dolphin slaughter that the documentary depicts. They may have moved one step closer to that goal with the news that the Oscar-nominated film, which shows a secret dolphin-killing field in Taiji, Japan, will now be distributed in Japan. The Japanese company Medallion Media is planning a tentative release date of April 2010, according to a statement released late Monday by the filmmakers' representatives. The director, Louie Psihoyos, considers the move a coup because the film had drawn the threat of legal action in Japan.
docs.abstract: The filmmakers may have moved one step closer to their goal of stopping the dolphin slaughter that the documentary depicts.

docs.snippet: The subject of an Oscar-nominated documentary about his leaking of the Pentagon Papers offers his critical take on "The Hurt Locker," "Nine" and more....
docs.lead_paragraph: "You bet!" Daniel Ellsberg told us by e-mail when we asked if he would be heading to the Oscars in March. The man who leaked the secret history of the Vietnam War is the subject of the documentary "The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers." Directed by Rick Goldsmith and Judith Ehrlich, the film has been nominated for a best documentary Oscar.
docs.abstract: The subject of an Oscar-nominated documentary about his leaking of the Pentagon Papers offers his critical take on "The Hurt Locker," "Nine" and more.

docs.snippet: A good Oscar narrative makes voters feel that they're completing a satisfying plotline, writes Mark Harris in New York magazine....
docs.lead_paragraph: Over at New York magazine, Mark Harris takes a spin through two exhausting weeks of Oscar campaigning. (Try doing it for three months, buddy.) And he gives a nice summation of what produces a victory: story line.
docs.abstract: A good Oscar narrative makes voters feel that they're completing a satisfying plotline, writes Mark Harris in New York magazine.

headline.main: A Story Line Straight to Oscar
